Regional rates
	Regional rates
		This section applies in respect of the year ending 31 March 2020.
		The regional rate to be levied on the rateable net annual values ofhereditaments is to be 34.01 pence in the pound.
		The regional rate to be levied on the rateable capital values ofhereditaments is to be 0.4574 pence in the pound.
		A rate specified in subsection (2) or (3) may be varied by an order made bythe Department under Article 7(1) of the Rates Order.
		An order made by virtue of subsection (4)—
			may be made only after the first occasion on which all the Ministerialoffices are filled after the passing of this Act, but
			may set the rate in respect of the whole of the year for which it is made.
		In this section—
			  * “the Ministerial offices” means— 
			the offices of First Minister and deputy First Minister, and
			the Ministerial offices to be held by Northern Ireland Ministers (within themeaning of the Northern Ireland Act 1998);
				  * “the Rates Order” means the Rates (Northern Ireland) Order 1977 ([S.I. 1977/2157 (N.I. 28))](/id/nisi/1977/2157?view=plain "Go to item of legislation"); 
				and any expression used in this section and in the Rates Order has the meaninggiven by that Order.
Renewable heat incentive scheme
	Introductory 
		The Renewable Heat Incentive Scheme Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2012([S.R. (NI) 2012 No. 396](/id/nisr/2012/396?view=plain "Go to item oflegislation")) (“the 2012 Regulations”) are amended in accordance withsections 3 and 4.
		Nothing in those sections affects the power to make regulations undersection 113 of the Energy Act 2011 amending or revoking any provision amendedor inserted by those sections.
	Tariffs for periodic support payments
		In regulation 36(3) for “(7B)” substitute “(7C)”.
		In regulation 36(5)—
			for “(7B)” substitute “(7C)”;
			for “or 4” substitute “, 4 or 5”.
		In regulation 36(6) for “(7B)” substitute “(7C)”.
		In regulation 36(7) after “(7B)” insert “or (7C)”.
		In regulation 36(7A) after “accredited on or after 18th November 2015”insert “, other than installations to which paragraph (7C) applies”.
		In regulation 36 after paragraph (7B) insert—
			“(7C)The tariffs for installations (whether accredited before or after thecoming into operation of section 3 of the Northern Ireland (Regional Rates andEnergy) Act 2019) falling within the small or medium biomass tariffs set outin Schedule 5—
			for the period beginning with 1st April 2019 and ending with 31st March2020, are the tariffs set out in Schedule 5;
			for each subsequent year commencing with 1st April and ending with the next31st March, are the tariffs applicable on the immediately preceding 31st Marchadjusted by the percentage increase or decrease in the consumer prices indexfor the previous calendar year (the resulting figure being rounded to thetenth of a penny, with any twentieth of a penny being rounded upwards).
			(7D)For the purposes of paragraph (7C) “the consumer prices index” means—
			the consumer prices index calculated and published by the Office forNational Statistics; or
			where the index is not published for a year, any substituted index orfigures published by that Office.”
		In regulation 36(8) for “(7B)” substitute “(7C)”.
		In regulation 36(9A) after “set out in Schedule 3A” insert “and the tarifffor the installation falls to be determined for the period mentioned inparagraph (7B)”.
		In regulation 36 after paragraph (9A) insert—
		“(9B)Where an accredited RHI installation falls within the small biomasstariff set out in Schedule 5—
			the tariff for the initial heat generated by the installation in any 12month period commencing with, or with the anniversary of, the date ofaccreditation (regardless of whether that date falls before or after thecoming into operation of section 3 of the Northern Ireland (Regional Rates andEnergy) Act 2019) is the Tier 1 tariff specified in Schedule 5;
			the tariff for further heat generated in that same 12 month period is therelevant Tier 2 tariff specified in Schedule 5.
			(9C)Where an accredited RHI installation falls within either of the mediumbiomass tariffs set out in Schedule 5—
			the tariff for the initial heat generated by the installation in any 12month period commencing with, or with the anniversary of, the date ofaccreditation (regardless of whether that date falls before or after thecoming into operation of section 3 of the Northern Ireland (Regional Rates andEnergy) Act 2019) is the relevant tariff specified in Schedule 5; and
			any further heat generated in that same 12 month period shall not beeligible for periodic payments.”
		In regulation 36(10) for “and (9A)” substitute “to (9C)”.
		In Schedules 3 and 4 omit the entries relating to small and medium biomassinstallations.
		After Schedule 4 insert the Schedule set out in the Schedule to this Act.
		Nothing in this section has effect in relation to periodic supportpayments (within the meaning of the 2012 Regulations) for heat generatedbefore this section comes into force.
	Voluntary buy-out arrangements
		After regulation 23A insert—
		“23BVoluntary buy-out arrangements
			The powers conferred by paragraph (2) may only be exercised in the periodwhile there is no Executive.
			The Department may, in respect of the financial year beginning with 1stApril 2019 and each of the two financial years immediately following, prepareand publish in such manner as it thinks appropriate arrangements (“buy-outarrangements”) which—
				enable a participant to apply in writing to the Department to receive apayment (“a buy-out payment”) in respect of an accredited RHI installation;
				set out the method by which the Department is to determine—
				whether a participant qualifies for a buy-out payment in respect of anaccredited RHI installation; and
				if the participant does qualify, the amount of that payment;
				where the Department determines that a participant does not qualify for abuy-out payment, require the Department to serve a notice on the participantstating that fact and setting out how the Department made that determination;
				where the Department determines that a participant qualifies for a buy-outpayment, require the Department to serve on the participant a notice (“a buy-out offer”) setting out—
				the proposed amount of that payment,
				how that payment is calculated, and
				the effect of paragraph (5);
				enable the participant to serve a notice on the Department accepting orrejecting the buy-out offer; and
				require the Department, subject to paragraph (4)(b), to make to aparticipant the buy-out payment proposed in a buy-out offer which has beenaccepted by the participant.
			The method referred to in paragraph (2)(b)—
				must be such as to take into account the amount of periodic supportpayments previously received by the participant in respect of the accreditedRHI installation; and
				may accordingly be such that the participant does not qualify for a buy-outpayment.
			The buy-out arrangements may contain such other provisions as appear to theDepartment to be necessary or expedient for the proper administration of thearrangements, including provisions—
				setting out the times at which, or the periods within which, the stepsmentioned in paragraph (2) must be taken by a participant or, as the case maybe, the Department;
				preventing a buy-out payment being made to a participant at any time whenperiodic support payments to the participant are being withheld or reducedunder Part 7 or are suspended under that Part;
				for the Department to suspend periodic support payments in respect of anaccredited RHI installation while an application in respect of thatinstallation is being dealt with under the arrangements;
				applying provisions of these regulations relating to the scheme to thearrangements (with or without modifications).
			Where in accordance with the buy-out arrangements, the Department makes abuy-out payment to a participant in respect of an accredited RHI installation,the installation ceases from the date of the payment to be an accredited RHIinstallation.
			In paragraph (1) “the period while there is no Executive” means the period—
				beginning with the coming into operation of section 4 of the NorthernIreland (Regional Rates and Energy) Act 2019; and
				ending on the next occasion when the offices of all of the Northern IrelandMinisters (including those of the First Minister and the deputy FirstMinister) are filled.”
	Duty to report on operation of buy-out arrangements
		The Department must, after the end of each financial year for which buy-outarrangements are published by it, prepare a report on the operation of thearrangements in that year.
		A report under this section in respect of a financial year must, inparticular, set out—
			the number of participants who have received a buy-out payment in thatyear, and
			the total amount of the buy-out payments made by the Department in thatyear.
		In the period while there is no Executive—
			the Department must send a report under this section to the Secretary ofState, and
			the Secretary of State must lay the report before Parliament.
		At any other time, the Department must lay a report under this sectionbefore the Northern Ireland Assembly.
		In this section “the Department”, “buy-out arrangements”, “buy-out payment”and “the period while there is no Executive” have the same meaning as inregulation 23B of the 2012 Regulations (inserted by section 4).
Final provisions
	Commencement 
		This section and sections 1 and 7 come into force on the day on which thisAct is passed.
		Sections 2 and 3 and the Schedule come into force on 1 April 2019.
		Sections 4 and 5 come into force at the end of the period of 2 monthsbeginning with the day on which this Act is passed.
	Extent and short title
		This Act extends to Northern Ireland only.
		This Act may be cited as the Northern Ireland (Regional Rates and Energy)Act 2019.
